The game is actually excellent, definitely an 8 out of 10. The problem is when you mix gamers and non-gamers. DO NOT DO THIS. What you will arrive at is obvious leaders untouchably separated by about game five or six, and the rest of the players beginning to understand they have no chance at winning or claiming even second place. And the catch-up mechanisms are FAR too weak to accommodate casual players.

This is what happened to us. We didn't finish the campaign because the non-gamers - who were actually the ones who kept asking to play over my own warnings and objections - were wiped out every time. One of them, the youngest (a teen), cried at the end of the final game - only round nine - after which I tossed it into the garbage.

Imagine a game where you are already in third place, best case scenario, and there are hours to go. How would that make most people feel? An campaign makes the ever-growing series of bleak losses worse and worse as everyone at the table sees the crushing ending awaiting dozens of hours away of pointless play.

Co-op campaign games work. But PvP campaign games are a pretty terrible idea unless everyone has essentially the same skill level. And this one masquerading as a casual game was all the worse for the disguise.

Completed a 3-player campaign, plated at a pace of one game per week.

I enjoy the original Ticket to Ride. I had fun with this campaign, but I cannot say Legacy is good. There are too many design decisions which with I cannot agree. It surprises me that this superstar design team would allow a product with such glaring oversights and lack of playtesting to be released, although perhaps that was due to the publisher's influence. I can't imagine Alan Moon is pleased with the soul of his magnum opus being tortured in this way.

Legacy is too quick at the beginning, too complicated in the middle, and too long at the end. Most mechanisms are only mildly interesting, and do not have a significant impact on decision-making within a given game. The story is decidedly low-concept and forgettable. Who is the intended audience of this legacy game? It seems too heavy to appeal to TTR fans, and too boring to appeal to legacy game fans.

On too many occasions, the reward structure is outright unknown. This uncertainty undermines much of the game’s content.

The extra content that gets unlocked varies widely, and can become overwhelming when much of it overlaps.

There are some flashes of brilliance, but they are small and mostly not legacy-dependent.

I hope TTR Legacy gets recognized as a swing and a miss for legacy games. It can still be loads of fun, but we should be open and honest about what doesn’t work in a board game, to improve games going forward. It’s a shame because there are a lot of great ideas in this box, but the execution just isn’t right.

While it was nice seeing the classic Ticket to Ride expanded to a legacy, game, and while the novelty of unlocking new parts of the country was always enjoyable, every mechanic that got added just seemed like more "stuff" that was only there to pad out the game.

Plus, we played with two players, which is fine for cooperative legacy games but certainly not for competitive ones. One of us began pulling ahead with four or five games left in the campaign, and the winner was never really in question after that. It just stopped being fun when you knew that no matter the outcome of each game, the winner of the campaign had already been decided.

Legends of the West is quite a spectacle, and it's nice that there's the option to keep playing after the legacy campaign is finished. But I already am not overly fond of the original game, and this legacy edition didn't change that.

Legacy version of Ticket to Ride. It starts with much less board, many less trains, and no points for length of train segments or longest train. You do get bonuses for playing segments of your own color, and for connecting to certain cities. Gradually the board expands, you get to piggyback on other's, and other new rules are introduced. It was fun, but the early rounds are less fun than traditional TTR.

It's nice, but there's a lot of randomness and luck involved. Depending on how lucky players were when drawing their connections, we had players score anything between 40 and 200 in the same round (11 + 12) from connections, with the roles reversed in another round, so it's not a skill issue.

If you happen to get two connections from the same city in the west to two neighboring cities in the east, you basically get twice the amount of dollars with the same work. OTOH if you only get small connections wildly distributed across the USA, you have no chance to score high. Same with drawing new cards during a round: are there several which have a large overlap with your existing network or are they all far off?

In the end, the player who won did so because he had three games with a lot of synergy in his connections while the others had just one or two.

Another thing which makes this a bit worse than some of the other legacy games we played (e.g. Charterstone and Queensdale) is the lack of a real catch-up mechanism. Points are hidden and the only "catch-up" is by giving the loser of the previous round some big advantages (start player + extra turn + first free connection(s)). It really helps to sit behind the player who loses more often than others (as our winner did), because that player will often be the start player and the player order remains clockwise, so even as the leader and/or winner of the previous round you still get to play second.

Ticket to Ride Legacy: Legends of the West was a fun legacy game. I am not a huge Ticket to Ride fan, but this one won me over. The campaign was varied and interesting. The excitement of expanding the board across the USA over several sessions was fun. Opening the boxes of hidden treasures was also exciting. Recommended.

However, we have never been enticed to revisit the post-legacy game. As it is untradeable, I may eventually scavenge usable parts and bin the rest.

FYI: : Spoiler-free review

As avid fans of Ticket to Ride, diving into our first campaign and Legacy game has been an exciting journey. We're currently on game 8 of the 12-game campaign, and it's been a fantastic experience so far!

For newcomers to the campaign and Legacy format (as we were), the introduction of new rules in each game can be slightly overwhelming. We even chose to skip the new rules in one session, and still had a great time.

However, we noticed that these rules might be challenging for older players, like those over 70, to grasp. This aspect prevents us from giving a perfect rating.

Based on our experience, here are some tips and insights (without spoilers):
- The campaign component is a one-time adventure. Post-campaign, the game remains replayable, with the final state of the campaign influencing future games.

- If you're new to campaign-style games, do a bit of research first. The initial complexity is manageable, and you'll quickly adapt.

- When playing with people skeptical to new games, or those who find new games and rules daunting, it helps if someone ine the group has researched extensively beforehand, even if it means encountering some spoilers. This preparation will allow you to smoothly guide everyone through the new gameplay.

- We've been playing as a duo, though four players are recommended. Despite this, our experience has been incredibly enjoyable!
